newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: Guatemala state utility to sell two power plants.
newsitem.headline: Guatemala state utility to sell two power plants.

text.p: The state-owned Guatemalan Electric Co (EEGSA) plans to sell two power plants through an international bidding process, as Congress prepares to approve a bill to end the government's monopoly on electric production and distribution, the Energy and Mines Ministry said Friday.
"We will open bidding for the Laguna plant and the Stewart and Stevenson turbine in order to capitalize the Guatemalan Electric Co," Henry Hernandez, a spokesman for the ministry, told Reuters.
Under the proposed General Electricity Law, which Congress is expected to pass next week, the new owners of the plants could sell electricity directly to consumers on the open market.

The EEGSA, which sells power to residents of the Guatemala City area, owes $115 million to the National Electrification Institute (INDE), also owned by the government. The INDE produces electricity that it sells to the EEGSA and directly to consumers outside the capital.
According to Hernandez, the ministry will form a commission, including members of religious and human rights group, to monitor the bidding process.
Hernandez said bidding would open soon after the commission was formed in late September. The ministry hopes to sell the thermoelectric plants by February, he said.

Hernandez said the Stewart and Stevenson plant, in the southern department of Escuintla, has a current capacity of 28 megawatts. The Laguna plant, in Amatitlan about 20 miles (32 km) south of Guatemala City, has a capacity of 80 megawatts.
